slidelink.displaytext: Untitled Scene
Untitled Slide
Which of the following antibodies is most frequently associated with the classic delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction?
Which test is most useful in aiding with the diagnosis red blood cell sensitization caused by drugs?
Which of the following blood types can receive A+ blood cells during transfusion?
Interpret the following results:
Which of the following anti-coagulants will extend the shelf-life of donated blood to 35 days?
When is radiated blood required?
Which of the following can result in an offspring who has HDFN?
What is the Fisher Race nomenclature for the genotype R2r?
Consider the following blood grouping reactions. What is a likely explanation for the discrepancy that is demonstrated by the results?
Consider the following blood grouping reactions. What is a likely explanation for the discrepancy that is demonstrated by the results?
Resistance to malaria is best associated with which of the following blood groups?
Eight units of platelets were pooled. What is the new expiration date of the pooled component?
What is the easiest way to help determine if a patient phenotypically expresses the genotype “sese”?

A woman comes into the hospital and delivers a stillborn at 34 weeks gestation. She is group O negative with a weak anti-D in her serum. You cannot obtain a specimen on the fetus or a transfusion / pregnancy history on the mother. What do you need to do?
Which of the following constitutes a permanent rejection status for a donor?
Given the information below, what antibody (antibodies) does this patient have?

A patient’s serum was found to be microscopically incompatible with 6 out of 6 donor units tested. When a cell panel was performed, ten out of ten cells were positive at room temperature and negative at 370C and negative in the AHG phase. The patient needs blood. What do you do?
If CDE/Cde red cells are transfused into a Cde/Cde person, what Rh antibody is most likely to be developed?
What is the likely cause for the discrepancy if an ABO typing is done on a newborn with the following results: Anti-A 3+ Anti-B (-) Anti-AB 3+ A cells (-) B cells (-)
Crossmatch is incompatible at room temperature and the auto-control is positive. The incompatibility decreases during the incubation phase. Give an explanation for these results.
Cryoprecipitate is best prepared by thawing FFP at what temperature?
Which of the following parental matings will give the greatest chance of producing an individual who expresses the Bombay phenotype?
Which of the following conditions would cause an individual to be permanently rejected as a blood donor?
Which of the following conditions would cause an individual to be permanently rejected as a blood donor?
You observe that the autocontrol and anti-D control are positive on immediate spin. Interpret your results.
Which of the following blood group antigens can be found in tears?
A newborn is typed as B- and needs a transfusion. You have no B- blood in inventory. What do you do?

While performing a blood grouping, you observe a “mixed field” reaction in the forward typing of a patient’s sample. What is a possible explanation for this phenomenon and how should you follow it up?
Interpret the following reactions:
U is a high frequency antigen. With what warm agglutinin is U associated?
What is the purpose of using cryoprecipitate?

A tech does a type and screen on a pre-surgical patient. The patient is type A and Rh negative. Indirect Coombs is positive but the Direct Coombs is negative. What is the next procedure that should be done on the patient’s blood?

A patient was admitted to the hospital with a GI bleed. Anti-Kell was detected in her serum. Four units of blood were cross-matched and found compatible at room temperature, 370C, and in the anti-globulin test. The check with sensitized Coombs control cells gave a positive 3+ reaction. Interpret the 3+ reaction.
A unit of packed red blood cells labeled group O, Rho (D) positive was incompatible in the anti-globulin phase of the crossmatch with three different recipients. What is the probable cause?
Your patient has a positive IAT screen. Your 3-donor panel work-up indicates that the patient has at least 2 significant antibodies. What is your next step?
A vaccination is part of which immunity type?
HIV infection infects which cell type?
Prozone condition exist as serological test to quantify antibody production in patient. What needs to be done before repeating test to avoid false negative result?
Which PCR enzyme that must be added to patient solution to help bind to complement nucleotide to DNA fragment.
U is related to which type of RBCs antigens?
A child born with dwarfism has lymph node devoid to T and B cells. What is the likely diagnose?
What disease are anti-beta cell antibody is associated with which disease?
Therapeutic phlebotomy is used to care for which condition?
What antibody is pentameric protein?
Donath Landsteiner antibody test is used for PCH. Which antigen does it detect?
What is correct about autologous blood donation?
which Hypersensitivity reaction type os characterized by immune complexes and complement activation?
Which complement factor is part of molecular attack unit?
The mother phenotype as AB blood and father phenotype as AB blood. What is the probable phenotype of the offspring ?
What is eluate used for?
Why is difficult to get ABO forward type from a newborn ?
Identify a specific component of the adaptive immune system that is formed in response to antigen stimulation?
What type of B cells are formed after antigen stimulation?
All of the following are immunologic functions of complement except:
Which region of the immunoglobulin molecule can bind to antigen?
Which region of the immunoglobulin molecule can bind to antigen?
What comprises the indicator system in an indirect ELISA for detecting antibody?
What is the titer in tube #8 if tube #1 is undiluted and dilutions are doubled?
Which method listed is the most sensitive test to detect congenital syphillis?
Which is most likely a positive Western Blot result for HIV infection?
Which antibody persists in low level carriers of hepatitis B virus?
Which genotype is heterozygous for C antigen?
What blood type is impossible for an offspring resulting from the mating of AO and BO individuals?
In the Hardy -Weinberg equation, what does p2 represent?
This type of antibody response is analogous to an anamnestic antibody reaction:
This type of antibody response is analogous to an anamnestic antibody reaction:
How is an individual with the genotype Dce/dce classified?
Testing reveals a weak D that reacts 1+ at the AHG phase of indirect antiglobulin test (IAT). Interpret the result:
Which antibody is frequently seen in patients with autoimmune hemolytic anemia?
Which antibody would not be detected by Group O screening cells?
What ABO type(s) may donate to any other ABO type?
How long must a recipient sample be kept in the blood bank following compatibility testing?
A patient has a hemolytic reaction to blood transfused 8 days ago. What is the most likely cause?
Which of the following is not a viable method for removing leukocytes from red cell components?
FFP can be transfused without regard for:
Which physical examination result is cause for rejecting a whole blood donor?
Kernicterus is caused by the effects of:
Draw from Blood bank 78Q
